prompt: Facts: Accused No. 1 (A-1, Rayavarapu Punnayya) and Accused No. 2 (A-2, Rayavarapu Jaggaraju) were charged in connection with the death of Jagannadham.; Incident occurred on June 13, 1969.; A quarrel took place between A-1, A-2 and the deceased (Jagannadham).; During the quarrel, A-1 stabbed the deceased with a spear ('barchi') in the abdomen.; The injury caused was a single penetrating wound to the abdomen.; The deceased was hospitalized and received medical treatment.; The deceased died on June 20, 1969, seven days after the incident.; Medical evidence (post-mortem report) established the cause of death as peritonitis and secondary shock resulting from the spear injury to the abdomen.; The Trial Court acquitted A-1 of the charge under Section 302 IPC, but convicted him under Section 324 IPC (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons). A-2 was also convicted under Section 324 IPC.; The State of Andhra Pradesh appealed the acquittal of A-1 under Section 302 IPC to the High Court.; The High Court allowed the State's appeal, set aside the acquittal under Section 302 IPC, and convicted A-1 under Section 302 IPC, sentencing him to life imprisonment. The High Court maintained A-2's conviction under Section 324 IPC.; A-1 (Rayavarapu Punnayya) appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 299 (Culpable Homicide), Section 300 (Murder), Section 300 Exception 4 (Sudden Fight), Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 304 (Punishment for Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder - Parts I and II), Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "A-1's act constitutes Murder under Section 300, Clause Thirdly. He intentionally caused a bodily injury (spear thrust to abdomen) which was objectively sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.", "precedents": ["Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)", "Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148)", "State of A.P. v. M. Sobhan Babu (2000) 10 SCC 481"]}, {"argument": "The High Court correctly reversed the Trial Court's acquittal under Sec 302, as the Trial Court failed to appreciate the gravity of the intended injury and its sufficiency to cause death.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (on powers of appellate court in appeals against acquittal)", "State of Rajasthan v. Ram Prasad (2001) 3 SCC 333 (Interference with acquittal justified if view taken by trial court is perverse or clearly erroneous)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The act falls under Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder (Section 304 IPC), likely Part II. A-1 lacked the specific intention required for Section 300 Clause Thirdly; he may have had knowledge that the act was likely to cause death, but not the intention to cause an injury sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.", "precedents": ["Chamru Budhwa v. State of Madhya Pradesh (AIR 1954 SC 652)", "Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1982) 3 SCC 185)", "Randhir Singh @ Dhire v. State of Punjab (2004) 13 SCC 129 (discussing distinction between 302 and 304)"]}, {"argument": "Alternatively, the case is covered by Exception 4 to Section 300 (Sudden Fight). The incident arose out of a sudden quarrel, occurred in the heat of passion, and A-1 did not take undue advantage or act in a cruel or unusual manner (single blow).", "precedents": ["Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana (2002) 3 SCC 327", "Surain Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1976 SC 2169)", "Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. (2003) 3 SCC 528"]}, {"argument": "The High Court erred in reversing the acquittal under Section 302. The Trial Court's view convicting under Section 324 was a possible and reasonable interpretation of the facts and intent.", "precedents": ["Ajit Singh Thakur Singh v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1981 SC 733)", "Ayodhya Singh v. State of Bihar (AIR 1974 SC 1880)", "Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154"]}]}
